translation.text: Maajh, Fifth Mehl:

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

translation.text: The Life of the World, the Sustainer of the Earth, has showered His Mercy;

melody.description: Raag Majh was composed by the Fifth Sikh Guru (Shri Guru Arjun Dev ji). The Raag’s origins are based in Punjabi Folk Music and its essence was inspired by the Majha regions traditions of ‘Ausian’; the game of waiting and yearning for the return of a loved one.The feelings evoked by this Raag have often been compared to that of a mother waiting for her child to return after a long period of separation. She has an anticipation and hope for the child’s return, although at the same moment she is painfully aware of the uncertainty of their return home. This Raag brings to life the emotion of extreme love and this is highlighted by the sorrow and anguish of separation.

author.author: Guru Arjan Dev
author.description:
Guru Arjan Dev [1563 - 1606] was the fifth Guru of the Sikhs, born at Goindval. He was the youngest of the three sons of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Sikh Guru.

Guru Arjan Dev finished the construction of the Harimandir Sahib, the Golden Temple, and compiled the first Sikh scripture, known as the Adi Granth. Shortly after he became the first martyr of the Sikh religion, which formed a turning point in the development of the faith.

text: ਗੁਰ ਕੇ ਚਰਣ ਵਸੇ ਮਨ ਮਾਹੀ ॥

translation.text: the Guru's Feet have come to dwell within my mind.

transliteration.text: gur kē charan vasē man māhī .

melody.description: Raag Majh was composed by the Fifth Sikh Guru (Shri Guru Arjun Dev ji). The Raag’s origins are based in Punjabi Folk Music and its essence was inspired by the Majha regions traditions of ‘Ausian’; the game of waiting and yearning for the return of a loved one.The feelings evoked by this Raag have often been compared to that of a mother waiting for her child to return after a long period of separation. This Raag brings to life the emotion of extreme love and this is highlighted by the sorrow and anguish of separation.

text: ਅੰਗੀਕਾਰੁ ਕੀਆ ਤਿਨਿ ਕਰਤੈ ਦੁਖ ਕਾ ਡੇਰਾ ਢਾਹਿਆ ਜੀਉ ॥੧॥

translation.text: The Creator has made me His Own. He has destroyed the city of sorrow. ||1||

transliteration.text: angīkār kīā tin karatai dukh kā dērā dhāhiā jīu .1.

translation.text: The True One abides within my mind and body;

translation.text: no place seems difficult to me now.

text: ਦੂਤ ਦੁਸਮਣ ਸਭਿ ਸਜਣ ਹੋਏ ਏਕੋ ਸੁਆਮੀ ਆਹਿਆ ਜੀਉ ॥੨॥

translation.text: All the evil-doers and enemies have now become my friends. I long only for my Lord and Master. ||2||

transliteration.text: dūt dusaman sabh sajan hōē ēkō suāmī āhiā jīu .2.

text: ਜੋ ਕਿਛੁ ਕਰੇ ਸੁ ਆਪੇ ਆਪੈ ॥

translation.text: Whatever He does, He does all by Himself.

transliteration.text: jō kish karē s āpē āpai .

text: ਆਪਣਿਆ ਸੰਤਾ ਨੋ ਆਪਿ ਸਹਾਈ ਪ੍ਰਭਿ ਭਰਮ ਭੁਲਾਵਾ ਲਾਹਿਆ ਜੀਉ ॥੩॥

translation.text: He Himself is the Helper and Support of His Saints. God has cast out my doubts and delusions. ||3||

transliteration.text: āpaniā santā nō āp sahāī prabh bharam bhulāvā lāhiā jīu .3.

translation.text: His Lotus Feet are the Support of His humble servants.

translation.text: Twenty-four hours a day, they deal in the Name of the Lord.

text: ਸਹਜ ਅਨੰਦ ਗਾਵਹਿ ਗੁਣ ਗੋਵਿੰਦ ਪ੍ਰਭ ਨਾਨਕ ਸਰਬ ਸਮਾਹਿਆ ਜੀਉ ॥੪॥੩੬॥੪੩॥

translation.text: In peace and pleasure, they sing the Glorious Praises of the Lord of the Universe. O Nanak, God is permeating everywhere. ||4||36||43||

transliteration.text: sahaj anand gāvah gun gōvind prabh nānak sarab samāhiā jīu .4.36.43.

text: ਸੋ ਸਚੁ ਮੰਦਰੁ ਜਿਤੁ ਸਚੁ ਧਿਆਈਐ ॥

translation.text: True is that temple, within which one meditates on the True Lord.

transliteration.text: sō sach mandar jit sach dhiāīai .

text: ਸੋ ਰਿਦਾ ਸੁਹੇਲਾ ਜਿਤੁ ਹਰਿ ਗੁਣ ਗਾਈਐ ॥

translation.text: Blessed is that heart, within which the Lord's Glorious Praises are sung.

transliteration.text: sō ridā suhēlā jit har gun gāīai .

text: ਸਾ ਧਰਤਿ ਸੁਹਾਵੀ ਜਿਤੁ ਵਸਹਿ ਹਰਿ ਜਨ ਸਚੇ ਨਾਮ ਵਿਟਹੁ ਕੁਰਬਾਣੋ ਜੀਉ ॥੧॥

translation.text: Beautiful is that land, where the Lord's humble servants dwell. I am a sacrifice to the True Name. ||1||

transliteration.text: sā dharat suhāvī jit vasah har jan sachē nām vitah kurabānō jīu .1.

translation.text: His Creative Power and His Bounties cannot be described.

text: ਧਿਆਇ ਧਿਆਇ ਜੀਵਹਿ ਜਨ ਤੇਰੇ ਸਚੁ ਸਬਦੁ ਮਨਿ ਮਾਣੋ ਜੀਉ ॥੨॥

translation.text: Your humble servants live by meditating, meditating on You. Their minds treasure the True Word of the Shabad. ||2||

transliteration.text: dhiāi dhiāi jīvah jan tērē sach sabad man mānō jīu .2.

text: ਰੰਗਿ ਰਤੇ ਤੇਰੈ ਤੁਧੁ ਭਾਵਹਿ ਸਚੁ ਨਾਮੁ ਨੀਸਾਣੋ ਜੀਉ ॥੩॥

translation.text: Those who are imbued with Your Love are pleasing to You. The True Name is their Banner and Insignia. ||3||

transliteration.text: rang ratē tērai tudh bhāvah sach nām nīsānō jīu .3.

translation.text: No one knows the limits of the True Lord.

melody.description: Raag Majh was composed by the Fifth Sikh Guru (Shri Guru Arjun Dev ji). The Raag’s origins are based in Punjabi Folk Music and its essence was inspired by the Majha regions traditions of ‘Ausian’; the game of waiting and yearning for the return of a loved one.The feelings evoked by this Raag have often been compared to that of a mother waiting for her child to return after a long period of separation. She has an anticipation and hope for the child’s return, although at the same moment she is painfully aware of the uncertainty of their return home. This Raag brings to life the emotion of extreme love and this is highlighted by the sorrow and anguish of separation.

author.author: Guru Arjan Dev

The Raag’s origins are based in Punjabi Folk Music and its essence was inspired by the Majha regions traditions of ‘Ausian’; the game of waiting and yearning for the return of a loved one.The feelings evoked by this Raag have often been compared to that of a mother waiting for her child to return after a long period of separation. She has an anticipation and hope for the child’s return, although at the same moment she is painfully aware of the uncertainty of their return home. This Raag brings to life the emotion of extreme love and this is highlighted by the sorrow and anguish of separation.

author.author: Guru Arjan Dev
author.description:
Guru Arjan Dev [1563 - 1606] was the fifth Guru of the Sikhs, born at Goindval. He was the youngest of the three sons of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Sikh Guru.

Guru Arjan Dev finished the construction of the Harimandir Sahib, the Golden Temple, and compiled the first Sikh scripture, known as the Adi Granth. Shortly after he became the first martyr of the Sikh religion, which formed a turning point in the development of the faith.
